I think that the wonderful thing that I learned

And what I found with all of them is that
even when they achieved success like what

34.text: most of us would consider the pinnacle.

I mean an Olympic gold medal is about as good

39.text:
They would then say, “Okay, I’m restless

44.text: myself down and take on the next challenge.”

And that, to me, was pretty spectacular to

50.text:
It’s like for them success is not a goal,
it’s just an ongoing journey.

55.text:
And every time they achieve something they
realize that there’s more of their own potential

61.text:
So to be Extreme You is to be maximizing every
aspect of your own personal potential, and

66.text:
that means really understanding who you are,
what are your unique gifts, what are your

72.text:
idiosyncrasies, what are the funny things

77.text: And also where are you not as strong?

And then when you understand that and then

88.text:
that is great about you and play your game

It’s incredibly fulfilling because I think
when you are playing to your greatest strengths,

98.text:
like we’ve all had that experience when

102.text:
just makes you thrive and you come into work

109.text: And that is what it feels like.

116.text:
of fit with who you are and you’re having

123.text:
So it feels pretty amazing to be Extreme You,

130.text:
are kind of pushing yourself outside your

Like you have the confidence to take on bigger

139.text:
because you know that you’re playing to

So the first thing I definitely say is, it’s
about what I call “checking yourself out”.

148.text:
And that means like really understanding what
you love and what your greatest skills are.

154.text:
And it’s funny, like there’s a lot of
media around there today saying to young people,

159.text:
you know, “Find your passion and then you’ll

161.text:
And I’m like, “You can’t do a Google

165.text:
You actually have to get out there and try

168.text: And get in there and really try it.

171.text: Like experience all sorts of different things.

173.text:
Because that’s when you’ll notice where

a duck to water and loved it, compared to

I mean I just didn’t have anything in common

And the feelings of being in those two different

to help me refine what was the most extreme

And I think everybody needs to get in and

213.text:
The reason I actually wrote this book in the

219.text:
I had finally, finally achieved some what

226.text:
I had led the turnaround of a five-billion

232.text:
And I started seeing articles that were written

239.text:
And it would say, ‘She did this great thing,
She did that great thing, She led this company.

245.text: She’s being called this in the media.

248.text:
And I literally would sit there squirming
in my chair going, “Oh my god.

255.text:
Because the truth is I’ve had some really
embarrassing fuck-ups along the way.

260.text:
And I think it’s important for young people
to see that those who become successful have

266.text:
had all those moments of uncertainty, all
those moments of frankly averageness.

270.text:
I mean I was that classic B-student, never
made the top sports team, never made the choir

278.text: Like never got picked for anything.

280.text:
But still I managed to go on learning and

287.text:
And I believe that that path exists for absolutely

291.text:
But we have a culture of success right now

295.text:
Like when you combine the world of social

301.text:
coiffed pictures into the world, and then

under 30 list—Everyone in the world is apparently

311.text:
Like it’s really hard to believe that you

318.text:
that it was possible, and then I went on this
mission to interview some really, really successful

326.text:
And I totally proved my case, because what

332.text:

338.text:
in the world did not start knowing that they

342.text:
Pretty much every one of them did not start

347.text:
Most of them ended up succeeding in a field
that was completely different to what they

353.text:
So it was a real story of willingness to experience

360.text: out where you’re going to thrive.

362.text:
And I think the last lesson in all of it was
that even those experiences early on where

367.text:
you feel like you’ve put X number of years
